title: How to Deploy a React App to a Subdirectory (/admin) on Hostinger Shared Hosting
paragraph:
Deploying a React frontend as an admin dashboard under a subdirectory like /admin on Hostinger is a smart way to keep your main site and internal tools organized on a single domain. This setup is ideal if you're running a main site with something like Next.js or WordPress on your root domain, and want to host your React-based admin panel separately but under the same roof.

In this step-by-step guide, weâ€™ll show you exactly how to deploy your React app to:

https://yourdomain.com/admin

using Hostingerâ€™s shared hosting.
content:
Prerequisites

Make sure you have the following ready:

A Hostinger shared hosting plan

A registered domain connected to Hostinger

Access to Hostingerâ€™s hPanel

A completed React project

Basic knowledge of React Router (for SPA routing)

Step 1: Set the Homepage and Build the App

In your React projectâ€™s package.json file, set the homepage field so React knows your app will live in a subdirectory:

"homepage": "https://yourdomain.com/admin"

Then build your app for production by running:

npm run build

Step 2: Upload Files to Hostinger

Log in to your Hostinger hPanel
Navigate to Files > File Manager
Open the public_html directory
Create a new folder called admin
Upload the contents of the build/ folder (not the folder itself) into public_html/admin/

Step 3: Configure .htaccess for React Router

If your React app uses React Router for client-side routing, create a file named .htaccess and paste the necessary rewrite rules inside public_html/admin/

Troubleshooting Tips

Clear cache, check folder paths, .htaccess, and make sure homepage is set.

No Node.js Needed

React builds are static, so Node.js isn't required.

Final Thoughts

This is a clean and effective way to organize multi-app frontends on a shared host.

title: ðŸš€ How to Deploy a Next.js Site to the Root Domain on Hostinger Shared Hosting
paragraph: Deploying a Next.js website to shared hosting like Hostinger is easier than you might thinkâ€”especially when you use Static HTML Exporting. This guide walks you through the full process of deploying your Next.js app to the root domain (e.g., https://yourdomain.com), bypassing the need for a Node.js server.
content:
Steps include setting output: 'export' in next.config.js, running build/export, and uploading the out/ folder's contents to public_html. For SPA routing, you may add an .htaccess file to rewrite routes.

Best suited for company sites, portfolios, blogs, and landing pages.

title: ðŸš€ Case Study: FastAPI Application Deployment on Ubuntu 24.04 VPS (Hostinger)
paragraph: Deploying a FastAPI backend on a VPS offers complete control over performance, security, and scalability. In this case study, we walk through the complete process of deploying a FastAPI application on a Hostinger VPS running Ubuntu 24.04. Weâ€™ll cover system setup, MongoDB installation, application service management using systemd, and configuring a reverse proxy with NGINX.
content:
Includes SSH setup, virtualenv creation, MongoDB 6.0 installation, Gunicorn service config, and NGINX reverse proxy setup.

Ideal for developers looking to manage full-stack deployment with flexibility.
